articles.headline: She Ran to Gunfire, and Ended It
articles.snippet: Kimberly Munley, who brought down the gunman, was on her way to have her car repaired when she jumped into action.
articles.abstract: Kimberly Munley, who brought down the gunman, was on her way to have her car repaired when she jumped into action.
articles.lead_paragraph: KILLEEN, Tex.  The police officer who brought down a gunman after he went on a shooting rampage at the Fort Hood Army base here was on the way to have her car repaired when she responded to a police radio report of gunfire at a center where soldiers are processed before being sent overseas, the authorities said Friday.

articles.headline: Money Issues That Can Test Even a Rock-Solid Marriage
articles.snippet: Money may be the root of all evil, and in a marriage it can certainly be the seed of trouble. Here are five things couples should do to sidestep difficulties.
articles.abstract: Money may be the root of all evil, and in a marriage it can certainly be the seed of trouble. Here are five things couples should do to sidestep difficulties.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a couple first gets together, they may not have the same approach to managing money. But it’s often easy enough to get past any differences when so much of the future is theoretical anyway.

articles.headline: Prospect of More U.S. Troops Worries Afghan Public
articles.snippet: Eight years of war have left people in Afghanistan exhausted, impatient and increasingly unsure that the Taliban can be defeated.
articles.abstract: Eight years of war have left people in Afghanistan exhausted, impatient and increasingly unsure that the Taliban can be defeated.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARIKAR, Afghanistan  As Americans, including President Obama’s top advisers, tensely debate whether to send more American troops to Afghanistan, Afghans themselves are having a similar discussion and voicing serious doubts.

articles.headline: Prep Schools Face Cuts in Student Aid
articles.snippet: The institutions’ endowments have suffered, making schools scramble for ways to keep their doors open to students who do not come from wealthy families.
articles.abstract: The institutions’ endowments have suffered, making schools scramble for ways to keep their doors open to students who do not come from wealthy families.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J.  For now, the nation’s biggest preparatory schools are protecting students like Ivy Alphonse-Leja, who depends on financial aid to attend the Lawrenceville School.

articles.headline: To Retain Its Bankers, Citi Offers Option Plan
articles.snippet: As an extra incentive to keep its bankers, Citigroup said it would grant one stock option at just above the current price for each share employees had accumulated.
articles.abstract: As an extra incentive to keep its bankers, Citigroup said it would grant one stock option at just above the current price for each share employees had accumulated.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hoping to encourage bankers and managers to stay, Citigroup began dispensing several million stock options this week to more than a quarter of its workers in a way that could result in a sizable gain for them.

articles.headline: Executives Are Wary After Arrests
articles.snippet: Recent arrests in an insider trading case have hedge fund managers and technology company leaders watching their words carefully.
articles.abstract: Recent arrests in an insider trading case have hedge fund managers and technology company leaders watching their words carefully.
articles.lead_paragraph: Switchboards at law firms have been lighting up in recent weeks as hedge fund managers and technology executives deluge lawyers with one question: What information is safe to share, in case the feds are listening?
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced, Claire Cain Miller and Zachery Kouwe

articles.headline: From Humdrum Day to a Scene of Chaos
articles.snippet: Survivors of the shooting say that in a few seconds, everything changed.
articles.abstract: Survivors of the shooting say that in a few seconds, everything changed.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT HOOD, Tex.   The Soldier Readiness Processing Center, a network of low buildings on Fort Hood, is as dreary as it sounds. It is where soldiers who are deploying overseas go to square away their medical paperwork. A visit means hearing tests, dental exams, shots and long, long lines.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson and Ray Rivera

articles.headline: Questioning a Test for Cancer
articles.snippet: Scaring people into quitting is the marketing rationale for a new genetic test, which purports to identify which smokers have the highest risk of developing lung cancer.
articles.abstract: Scaring people into quitting is the marketing rationale for a new genetic test, which purports to identify which smokers have the highest risk of developing lung cancer.
articles.lead_paragraph: Christopher Taylor says he never lasted more than a week when he tried to quit smoking in the past. But it has been four weeks and counting this time, since a genetic test indicated he had a much higher risk of developing lung cancer than the average smoker.

articles.headline: Broader Measure of U.S. Unemployment Stands at 17.5%
articles.snippet: The official jobless rate excludes millions of people who have given up looking for work and part-time workers who want to be working full time.
articles.abstract: The official jobless rate excludes millions of people who have given up looking for work and part-time workers who want to be working full time.
articles.lead_paragraph: For all the pain caused by the Great Recession, the job market still was not in as bad shape as it had been during the depths of the early 1980s recession  until now.

articles.headline: Virtual Goods Start Bringing Real Paydays
articles.snippet: It is quickly becoming commonplace for people to spend a few dollars to get ahead in an online game or to give a friend a gift on a social network.
articles.abstract: It is quickly becoming commonplace for people to spend a few dollars to get ahead in an online game or to give a friend a gift on a social network.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Silicon Valley may have discovered the perfect business: charging real money for products that do not exist.
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller and Brad Stone

articles.headline: With Wall Just a Memory, German Divisions Fade
articles.snippet: Germany is now more peaceful, more united and less turbulent than people had expected.
articles.abstract: Germany is now more peaceful, more united and less turbulent than people had expected.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN  “The Quiz of the Germans,” a lighthearted entry amid a crush of serious examinations of the 20th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall, pitted three West German celebrities seated behind the sloping hood of an old Volkswagen Beetle against counterparts from the East perched above the front of a clunky Trabant.

articles.headline: Windfall Seen as Bank Bonuses Are Paid in Stock
articles.snippet: Bankers are likely to make unusually large gains on the stock grants and options they received after shares in their companies fell sharply.
articles.abstract: Bankers are likely to make unusually large gains on the stock grants and options they received after shares in their companies fell sharply.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as Washington tries to rein in Wall Street pay, bankers are likely to make unusually large gains on the stock grants and options they received after shares in their companies fell sharply during the financial meltdown.

articles.headline: At Ruby Tuesday, Casual Dining Dons a Blazer
articles.snippet: In the recent downturn, Ruby Tuesday has tried to trade up. When people start to dine out again, the founder wants them to find his chain transformed.
articles.abstract: In the recent downturn, Ruby Tuesday has tried to trade up. When people start to dine out again, the founder wants them to find his chain transformed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Maryville, Tenn.

articles.headline: Inside the Global Gold Frenzy
articles.snippet: Amid a global frenzy fed by hedge funds, speculators and governments all rushing to stock up, the price of gold briefly surpassed $1,100 an ounce on Friday, a record high.
articles.abstract: Amid a global frenzy fed by hedge funds, speculators and governments all rushing to stock up, the price of gold briefly surpassed $1,100 an ounce on Friday, a record high.
articles.lead_paragraph: MENDRISIO, Switzerland

articles.headline: A Way Out of the Deep Freeze
articles.snippet: Judges overseeing at least 23 class actions relating to auction-rate securities have dismissed them in recent months. What’s a trapped investor to do?
articles.abstract: Judges overseeing at least 23 class actions relating to auction-rate securities have dismissed them in recent months. What’s a trapped investor to do?
articles.lead_paragraph: FOR many holders of auction-rate securities  investments that Wall Street once peddled as safe, sound and as fully liquid as cash  life in the frozen zone drags on.

articles.headline: Painful Stories Take a Toll on Military Therapists
articles.snippet: Those who treat soldiers’ psychological wounds say last week’s rampage highlights the strains of their profession.
articles.abstract: Those who treat soldiers’ psychological wounds say last week’s rampage highlights the strains of their profession.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many of the patients who fill the day are bereft, angry, broken. Their experiences are gruesome, their distress lasting and the process of recovery exhausting. The repeated stories of battle and loss can leave the most professional therapist numb or angry.
articles.byline: By Benedict Carey, Damien Cave and Lizette Alvarez

articles.headline: Little Evidence of Terror Plot in Base Killings
articles.snippet: Investigators believe that Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan acted under emotional, ideological and religious pressures.
articles.abstract: Investigators believe that Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan acted under emotional, ideological and religious pressures.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  After two days of inquiry into the mass shooting at Fort Hood, investigators have tentatively concluded that it was not part of a terrorist plot.
articles.byline: By David Johnston and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Iraq Passes Crucial Election Law
articles.snippet: After weeks of stalemate, lawmakers approved a law to administer a critical election that could determine how quickly U.S. combat forces leave.
articles.abstract: After weeks of stalemate, lawmakers approved a law to administer a critical election that could determine how quickly U.S. combat forces leave.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  After weeks of political stalemate, Iraq approved a law on Sunday to administer a critical national election in January, a significant milestone for its fragile democracy and a step that will allow the rapid withdrawal of American combat forces early next year.
articles.byline: By TIMOTHY WILLIAMS  and SA'AD IZZI

articles.headline: At 91, Mandela Endures as South Africa’s Ideal
articles.snippet: Even as Nelson Mandela fades from view, he retains a vital place in South Africa’s public consciousness.
articles.abstract: Even as Nelson Mandela fades from view, he retains a vital place in South Africa’s public consciousness.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG  The icon is a very old man now. His hair is white, his body frail. Visitors say Nelson Mandela leans heavily on a cane when he walks into his study. He slips off his shoes, lowers himself into a stiff-backed chair and lifts each leg onto a cushioned stool. His wife, Graça, adjusts his feet “so they’re symmetrical, and gives him a peck,” says George Bizos, his old friend and lawyer.

articles.headline: News Erupts, and So Does a Web Debut
articles.snippet: As major news erupted in Texas, a new 12-person Web-based newsroom had its debut as a nonprofit covering state government.
articles.abstract: As major news erupted in Texas, a new 12-person Web-based newsroom had its debut as a nonprofit covering state government.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Thursday afternoon, when word came about the shootings that left 13 people dead at Fort Hood, just up the road from Austin, it seemed like a made-to-order test for The Texas Tribune, a brand new 12-person Web-based newsroom.

articles.headline: A Movie’s Budget Pops From the Screen
articles.snippet: Just in case box-office receipts for “Avatar” fall short, Fox has worked hard to hedge its large bet on the movie.
articles.abstract: Just in case box-office receipts for “Avatar” fall short, Fox has worked hard to hedge its large bet on the movie.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Can a movie studio make money on a film based on an original and unfamiliar story, with no Hollywood superstars, a vanishing DVD market and a price tag approaching $500 million?

articles.headline: A Netflix Model for Haute Couture
articles.snippet: Rent the Runway wants to do for high-end fashion what Netflix has done for movies by offering a simple mail-order system.
articles.abstract: Rent the Runway wants to do for high-end fashion what Netflix has done for movies by offering a simple mail-order system.
articles.lead_paragraph: For many women, a $1,000 dress is something they admire in the pages of a glossy magazine or see draped on the frame of a celebrity  not an item hanging in their closet.

articles.headline: Medical Industry Grumbles, but It Stands to Gain
articles.snippet: Many analysts say the House bill is not as bad for business as many in the health care industry might have feared when the overhaul effort began.
articles.abstract: Many analysts say the House bill is not as bad for business as many in the health care industry might have feared when the overhaul effort began.
articles.lead_paragraph: For any industry, there has to be at least some good news any time Congress votes to expand the market by tens of millions of customers.
articles.byline: By Duff Wilson and Reed Abelson

articles.headline: Sober Mood at New York Post as Circulation Spirals Lower
articles.snippet: Nearly every paper in America has lost circulation, but The New York Post more than most — down almost 30 percent in 2.5 years.
articles.abstract: Nearly every paper in America has lost circulation, but The New York Post more than most — down almost 30 percent in 2.5 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three years ago, Col Allan, the editor of The New York Post, pumped his fist and waded into a cheering crowd at a Midtown restaurant, celebrating The Post’s overtaking its rival, The Daily News, in weekday circulation. The Post trumpeted the news on a Times Square billboard and in its pages.

articles.headline: Complications Grow for Muslims Serving in U.S. Military
articles.snippet: In the years since Sept. 11, the service of Muslim-Americans is more necessary and more complicated than ever.
articles.abstract: In the years since Sept. 11, the service of Muslim-Americans is more necessary and more complicated than ever.
articles.lead_paragraph: Abdi Akgun joined the Marines in August of 2000, fresh out of high school and eager to serve his country. As a Muslim, the attacks of Sept. 11 only steeled his resolve to fight terrorism.

articles.headline: Fort Hood Gunman Gave Signals Before His Rampage
articles.snippet: Relatives of Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan say stress that led to the shooting had been building for a long time.
articles.abstract: Relatives of Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan say stress that led to the shooting had been building for a long time.
articles.lead_paragraph: KILLEEN, Tex.  It was still dark on Thursday when Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan left his aging apartment complex to attend 6 a.m. prayers at the brick mosque near Fort Hood. Afterward, he said goodbye to his friends there and asked forgiveness from one man for any past offenses.
articles.byline: By James C. McKinley Jr. and James Dao

articles.headline: For Abortion Foes, a Victory in Health Care Vote
articles.snippet: Lobbying by Catholic bishops helped push a block on using federal subsidies for insurance covering elective abortions.
articles.abstract: Lobbying by Catholic bishops helped push a block on using federal subsidies for insurance covering elective abortions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  A restriction on abortion coverage, added late Saturday to the health care bill passed by the House, has energized abortion opponents with their biggest victory in years  emboldening them for a pitched battle in the Senate.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Robert Pear

articles.headline: Market Rally Continues in Asia
articles.snippet: Asian markets opened strong Tuesday, a day after the Dow Jones Industrial Average reached a new high for 2009.
articles.abstract: Asian markets opened strong Tuesday, a day after the Dow Jones Industrial Average reached a new high for 2009.
articles.lead_paragraph: If the economy is getting stronger, why is the dollar getting weaker?
